newsitem.title: CANADA: Senate motion to kill Canadian MMT bill fails.
newsitem.headline: Senate motion to kill Canadian MMT bill fails.

text.p: A motion in the Canadian Senate that would have effectively killed a government bill to ban the import and interprovincial trade of the gasoline additive MMT, failed on Thursday, a Senate official said.

The motion by Conservative Senator Noel Kinsella would have asked the Royal Society of Canada to study the effects of MMT, which the Liberal government wants to ban on environmental and health grounds.
If Kinsella's motion had succeeded, the Senate would not likely have been able to pass the bill before a general election expected this year, possibly for June.
Analysts had seen the motion as a test of how strong opposition to the bill was in the unelected Senate, the upper chambers of Parliament. The House of Commons passed the bill in December.
Senate Deputy Clerk Richard Greene said consideration of the bill was now adjourned until after the Senate returned from its Easter vacation on April 8.
Ethyl Corp of Virginia makes MMT and would be shut out of Canadian market if the bill passed.
MMT stands for methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl and has been used as a replacement for lead as an octante booster.

But car companies said it gummed up their on-board diagnostic systems and some experts said it could be unhealthy. Ethyl challenged that and Kinsella had sought to find proof before forcing expensive retooling in the oil industry.
